node.title: 6 New California Laws You Should Know About
node.alt: A delivery worker finishing his job through the courier app Postmates in Los Angeles.
node.description: Changes to the minimum wage, composting rules, police procedures and more.
node.content: ["A new year is upon us, and 2022 means not only the arrival of Year 3 of the coronavirus pandemic (yikes), but also the implementation of hundreds of new laws in California.", "There are far too many to list, so today I\u2019m highlighting six important changes that went into effect on Jan. 1. Later in the week, I\u2019ll share some more new laws worth knowing about.", "This new law prohibits food-delivery apps, such as DoorDash and Uber Eats, from keeping any portion of gratuity meant for restaurant workers. The rule also requires that the companies itemize customers\u2019 bills and disclose all added fees.", "The measure is an effort to increase billing transparency and regulate the growing app-based food-delivery industry.", "All California voters will receive mail-in ballots for future elections, regardless of whether they signed up for absentee voting.", "Californians have already gotten a taste of universal mail-in voting during the pandemic, but the official change makes California the eighth state in the nation with such a law.", "As of Jan. 1, businesses with more than 25 employees must pay their employees at least $15 an hour, while smaller businesses must offer at least $14 hourly.", "The raises are the latest consequence of a landmark law that pushed the state\u2019s minimum wage to the highest in the nation. It\u2019s important to note, however, that cities such as Los Angeles and San Francisco already required employers to pay at least $15 an hour.", "Californians are now required to toss excess food waste into green waste bins, rather than the trash, as the state embarks on the largest mandatory composting effort in the nation.", "The law requires that local governments provide organic recycling collection to all residents and businesses. The effort is intended to keep landfills clear of food scraps, which contribute significantly to greenhouse gas emissions.", "Read more from The Associated Press.", "Law enforcement agencies are now prohibited from posting on social media the mug shots of most people arrested and accused of nonviolent crimes.", "Supporters of the new rules say that publishing such photos on Twitter and Facebook can irreparably harm the lives of people who have not yet been proven guilty.", "This law eliminated the section on spousal rape in the California penal code to ensure that people convicted of raping their spouses face the same punishments as other rapists.", "Groups that advocated for the change said that state law had previously allowed more lenient treatment of people who raped their spouses, and that many such perpetrators had not been not required to register as sex offenders.", "Los Angeles is America\u2019s sprawling sushi capital.", "Today\u2019s travel tip comes from Paul Spitzmueller, a reader who lives in and recommends Oakland:", "Tell us about your favorite places to visit in California. Email your suggestions to CAtoday@nytimes.com. We\u2019ll be sharing more in upcoming editions of the newsletter.", "What\u2019s the best part of winter in California? Email us at CAtoday@nytimes.com with your traditions, recommendations and opinions.", "On Dec. 22, Darrick Lo and Adrienne Lei married at San Francisco City Hall in front of their family, friends and cat, Nina.", "Years earlier, in 2015, the two met at an art museum in New York City. Lo approached Lei and said hello, but left without giving her his phone number. The two had no way to contact one another.", "So how did they end up together?", "Read the story in The Times.", "Thanks for reading. I\u2019ll be back tomorrow. \u2014 Soumya", "P.S. Here\u2019s today\u2019s Mini Crossword, and a clue: Library stock (5 letters).", "Jordan Allen and Jonah Candelario contributed to California Today. You can reach the team at CAtoday@nytimes.com.", "Sign up here to get this newsletter in your inbox."]
